qas.question: During what century did gold coinage cease?
Coinage from what metal replaced gold coinage?
What was the Anglo-Saxon silver coin called?
What was another name for the denarius?
In what part of Europe were gold coins still minted?

context: The various Germanic states in the west all had coinages that imitated existing Roman and Byzantine forms. Gold continued to be minted until the end of the <a0_0>7th<a0_0/> century, when it was replaced by <a1_0>silver<a1_0/> coins. The basic Frankish silver coin was the denarius or <a3_0>denier<a3_0/>, while the Anglo-Saxon version was called a <a2_0>penny<a2_0/>. From these areas, the denier or penny spread throughout Europe during the centuries from 700 to 1000. Copper or bronze coins were not struck, nor were gold except in <a4_0>Southern Europe<a4_0/>. No silver coins denominated in multiple units were minted.
